awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Frequency Domain Conversion of Computer Aided Design Files to Enable Encryption, Authentication and Feature Search Function
awd_abstract_narration:
The additive manufacturing (AM) or 3D printing market has developed exponentially from $1.1B in 2009 to $7.3B in 2018 and experts estimate this to grow double in the next four years. Despite the strategic role that computer-aided design (CAD) files play in AM, designers develop, store, and use the CAD models as they do in any other manufacturing method. This study will research a novel method of imparting new functionalities in CAD models by converting them to the frequency domain using lossless algorithms. The frequency domain representation allows searching the files for specific design features of interest, which is not feasible in the current CAD file formats. Transformation to the frequency domain opens up possibilities for developing new compression and encryption methods. 

Analysis will be conducted to determine the fundamental principles that lead to lossless conversion of CAD files to the frequency domain and develop compression and encryption methods for the files. Wavelet transform and dynamic time warping will be among the methods used for implementing search functionalities. Dynamic window selection and scaling methods will be used to perform feature search with and without scaling of the object size. These algorithms are based on an exact match procedure and do not rely on tuning or learning the algorithm.  The project will help industries that are using AM methods, for example, the aerospace, automotive, medical and military equipment industries. Development of these unique capabilities will by provide new capabilities for design, search, and security. The project will involve post-doctoral fellows and graduate students in the research. The dissemination plan will include publishing the results in journals, conference presentations and press releases for public awareness using the news media.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
A new generation of manufacturing processes is taking shape by integrating computer technologies with modern manufacturing systems. New cyber-manufacturing methods are becoming increasingly popular, and additive manufacturing has the potential to revolutionize our industries. These manufacturing methods rely heavily on special computer-aided design (also called CAD) files that encode the digital representation of physical objects, such as manufacturing components. One key benefit of cyber-manufacturing is the inherent ability to allow collaborative design among different entities using cloud computing and decentralized infrastructure, and the exchange of CAD files among distributed teams becomes an inherent part of the process.

To fully realize the opportunities offered by such distributed design capabilities, it is imperative that designers are able to search for three-dimensional (3D) objects in their databases. This project introduces a new search capability that has the potential to revolutionize manufacturing, by allowing designers to retrieve similar 3D objects based only on their shape, without relying on human-readable tags and text descriptors. The developed techniques offer the ability to search for exact and partial matches in large databases based on the shape of the given CAD files in a query.

The developed methods would help improve the productivity of CAD designers in modern manufacturing processes, which has the potential to lower the associated production costs and enable faster turnaround times. The potential economic benefits of such efficiencies will also allow cheaper digitally manufactured goods to be available. In the context of additive manufacturing, these efficiencies have the potential to increase local, just-in-time manufacturing using digitally-shared CAD files, leading to reductions in shipping of manufactured goods across the country, which can further reduce carbon emissions and positively impact the environment.


Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: Nektarios G Tsoutsos

Images (1 of )
  • Adaptive Manufacturing process chain including both the design and manufacturing phases. This project introduces an all-encompassing search engine, which can retrieve 3D objects based on artifacts at different stages of the manufacturing process (stereolithography, toolpaths, printed objects).
    Nektarios Tsoutsos
    Copyrighted
    Nektarios G Tsoutsos
    Adaptive Manufacturing process chain
  • Overview of shape-based search methodology for 3D models: thisproject employs frequency spectrograms to search for patterns that indicatesimilar shape characteristics.
    Dimitris Mouris
    Copyrighted
    Nektarios G Tsoutsos
    Overview of shape-based search methodology for 3D models
